div.head: THE PASSAGE OF THE FLEET.
div.p: Significant news reaches us to-day from Singapore. Two Japanese battleships, two firstclass and two second-class cruisers, and twelve destroyers are said to be near Singapore, steaming West. This is, so to speak, the preliminary to the lifting of the curtain on the, third act of the great Asiatic drama, and the interest therein will naturally be intensified. The first act succeeded in disturbing the equan imity of the whole world, the second is still in process of enactment, as the Russian Admiral and his fateful ships advance across the Indian seas, to that vast dislocated barrier of land which, like the vertebre of some prediluvial monster, stretches across his further course into the Pacific. It is at this point that the curtain will ring up on the third and last act. And here also it is just pos able that a certain obscurity may fall upon the movements of the Musovice fees, which, if doomed to press on, may, it is thought, have planned to pass into what is virtually the field of battle by some gate at which it may be least expected. Now, there can be little doubt that Kodjestvensky's first object is not to "find and destroy" his enemy, but to evade him by hook or by crook, and get his ships and inen into Vladivostok before staking everything on an encounter with the sea-kings of the Mikado. If there were any pos sibility of preparing his ships for battle, after their long sea voyage, at any point west of the Straits, he might as presumably his force is intended to fight-enter the China seas with drums beating and banners displayed. But it is his fate to lack any such harbour of refuge nearer than the distant goal to which he is bound, and between which and himself lurk the warships of his redoubtable foe.

The momentous question which thus arises is-How does Rodjestvensky hope to reach Vladivostok without fighting? And the solution of this problem gives birth to a situation of unparalleled interest. Whether he succeeds or not mast first of all largely depend upon the passage by which he takes his ships into the Pacific, and the efficiency of the Japanese Intelligence. A reference to the map will show that to pass through the "Gates of the East," he must make choice of a series of defiles through that great barrier of islands extending for 1,800 miles from the north-western point of Sumatra to Timor on the east, the last 500 miles from the North Australian coast. The two largest of these defiles, the Straits of Malacos and of Sunda, are the usual routes between East and West. The former is in length about 500 miles, with a breadth varying from about 300 to 25 miles, and it is here that the Japanese ships spoken of are at present found. There are several islands within the straits, and the exit, in view of a possible attack, is imperilled by a host of islands of various sizes. Purther east the Straits of Sunda, between the great islands of Sumatra and Java, would afford a quicker passage, as they are not more than 90 miles in length. Their passage, however, is similarly endangered by the existence of a number of islands and islets. Moreover, both straits narrow considerably towards their eastern mouths, which must add greatly to their perils from a naval point of view. Further eastward may be noticed a series of minor passes through the long chain of islands, as far as Timor, But these narrow waters, as well as those beyond, swarming with countless archipelagoes, are still very incompletely surveyed, and would be fraught with serious navigating dangers to such a fleet, which it might well hesitate to encounter.

There is one other important consideration which will conceivably influence the Russian point of passage, namely, the radius of action. possessed by the Japanese warships. The coal capacity of the latter has largely been sacrific ed to armament. But it must be remembered that Japau now possesses in Formosa a valu able advanced base for any southward naval action, and thence will be able to work fast colliers down to any of the numerous and insig nificant islands, whose neutrality may safely be regarded as a negligible quantity. We may take it, therefore, that there will be nothing" to prevent Togo from operating, with his cruisers and destroyers, in the neighbourhood of the straits, if he so chooses, and there is one possibility which, in view of recent happenings, the Japanese cannot afford to lose sight of The chance that the Ro sians may attempt to force themselves upon the hospitality of the French at Saigon for any final tinkering is one that takes Japanese surveillance of this port a serious necessity. This port, indeed, is the great danger point in the China seas, as any assist ance afforded by the French at this stage similar to that at Cherbourg and Algiers, could tairly be regarded by the Japanese as an act of war, entitling them to appeal to their allian In view, therefore, of Japanese vigilance at this point, it is highly probable that the Kas sians will choose one of the more easterly passages, and endeavour to reach Vladivostok to the east of the Philippines, through the Straits of Macassar, or the Molucca passage

div.head:
NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
ENGLISH IN PAY OF RUSSIA.
div.p: Acceding to the newspapers, it has been ascertained that the agents, mentioned in yesterday's telugu, are two better class English seafarers named Walsh and Bennett Dating an interview, they admitted being in the Russian employ and stated they had obtained four statements confirming the presence of torpedo boats, the declarations being signed before the Russian Consel. They denied the allegation of bribery, and stated their informants were only compensated for their
The Consal, who is also an Englishman, was interviewed, and stated that he anticipated an official statement would be issued shortly. His duty was merely to take down declarations.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive attended midday prayers today at Abeleon Mosque.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE'S YACHT.
div.p: Messrs. Inglis, shipbuilders, of Glasgow, have contracted to fit on board the Khedive's yacht Mahroussa turbine engines of the Par sons type. The yacht will be taken to the Clyde to have the alteration completed at the beginning of next month.

div.head: RAILWAY COMMISSION'S REPORT
div.p: We understand that the report of Lord Farrer's Railway Commission will not be given to the public in its entirety. The passages dealing with the personnel will remain for ever, hidden in the pigeon-holes of the Finanos Ministry. This is, perhaps, inevitable, but we should like to have heard the Commission's opinion on the subject.

div.head: MENSHAWI PASHA'S FUNERAL
div.p: -The death of the grea philanthropist Menshawi Pasha caused moch profound grief in Tantah that most of the inhabitants neglected their work from the early morning in expectation of the arrival of the mortal remains of the deceased from Cairo for burial. It was 4 pm, when the special train conveying the corpse reached Tantah station, where a multitude of people had gathered. The route taken from the station was through the Mondiriob-street to Bourse-street, which almost entirely belonged to the deceased. Shops were shut, and lanterns, draped in mournful crape, were lit. It was indeed an impressive scene.

The cortego was thus arranged:-First came the fikis with flags, then the students of Saied El Badawi, who read some verses from the Koran in a loud voice that caused some disorder. Two bands from Alexandria, consisting of the Porters' School and Urwa el Woska, played mournful dirges, and were followed by the notables of different localities. Then came the bier, surrounded by mounted police, who accompanied it till the procession resched the burial ground, which is in front of the girls' school established by the deceased. Many panegyrios were recited, at the conclusion of which the crowd dispersed.
In his will, Menshawi Paaba expressed the wish that a mosque should be built over his grave.

div.head: ANOTHER PLAGUE CASE AT SUEZ
div.p: Last Tuesday afternoon, a native, employed by Ib. Ghelidan Bey as storekeeper, was suddenly taken ill and coveyed to the Egyptian Government Hospital for treat ment, where the case was characterised as one of suspected babonic plague. The patient died next day, and the case was officially declared yesterday to be bubonic plague."
On account of this fresh case Suez is again declared to be infected, and the Quarantine Office has applied the usual measures of precaution for steamers communicating with the port.
Today's bulletin records another case at Sue

div.head: MORE WATER.
div.p: The Alexandria Water Company has decided to reduce the price of water supplied to the Municipality from 20 centimes to 15 centimes per cubic metre, so as to facilitate the employment of a larger quantity of water for the needs of the town.

div.head: BRITISH RECREATION CLUB
div.p: Among the seasonable entertainments of the day no more successful one will take place than that given last night, s day or two in advance of Xmas, at the above club. In the handsomely decorated hall wis a large Christmas tree, the gift of Mr. Curtis of Boulac, which proved from first to last a never ending source of attraction to the children of all ages who thronged around it till the distribution of the toys and other articles hung on its branches took place. We say from first to last, but an exception must be made of the time when the youngsters were regaling themselves in the tos tente. Of these, there were three, all tastefully decorated with evergreens and flags. The Earl and Countess of Cromer arrived on the scene at 5 o'clock, and were escorted by the president of the club to where the children were enjoying s themselves at tea. Something like 120 to 140 English children were there, boys and girls of all ages, from the little mite of one year to the lads and lasses of 15, or even more. The Very Rev. Dean and Mrs. Butcher were present, as well as many local celebrities. A elever ventriloquial entertainment concluded this very enjoyable children's fête, the arrangements for which were carried out by the entertainment com mittee in a manner that reflects the greatest credit on the club. Everything was thought of even a provision against possible emergency was provided for by the attendance of men from the Fire Brigade.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The 88. "Castillian Prince," from Antwerp and Middlesbrough, left Malta on Thursday and is due here on Monday next, with general cargo, &c.

div.head:
THE DUCHESS OF AOSTA.
TO PASS WINTER IN EGYPT.
div.p: The New York Herald (Paris) states that when the convalescent period is reached, the Duchess Helene of Aosta, who is now lying ill at Milan, will be brought to Egypt, where she will spend the winter.

div.head: COLD STORAGE IN EGYPT,
div.p: We learn that Mr. Harris, the principal authority in Europe and Americs on cold storage, will shortly arrive in Egypt in order to inspect the installations of the Nile Cold Storage Company at Cairo, Alexandria, and Port Said.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND).
div.p: A circular has been-issued to the directors of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd., informing shareholders that since the formation of the company they have succeeded in securing, on reasonable terms, some 700 feddans of building land, suitable for early development. For these transactions, large proportion ofthe present capital has been either expended orear-marked, andithas become evident to the Board that the existing dspital i insufficient to carry out the objects of the company and to enable them to complete nege cistions now in hand for other favorably situated lands, which it is desirable to secure at an early date.. It is, therefore, in their opinion, necessary to increase the capital of the company at once. With this object an extraordinary general meeting has been convened for the 10th January, 1905, when a resolution will be submitted to the proprietors increasing the share capital of the company by £150,000, of which it is proposed to issue, say, £100,000 pro rata to the shareholders at a price to be fixed hereafter.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: With reference to the interview pablished in Another column on this subject, it may be recalled that so far back as 1882, shipowners were very dissatisfied with the treatment meted out to them by the Suez Canal authorities, so much so that schemes for rival enterprises were started, and in the end three sets of plans were drawn up. One was for a freshwater canal from Alexandria to Cairo, and thence via Tel-el-Kebir to Suez. Another project was to construct a canal from Alexmndria to Mansourah and Ismailis, and thence to Saes, by s route parallel to the original danal. The third ides was to construct a econd Suez Canal, such as is now proposed by Sir T. Angier.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Commission municipale s'est réunie le 21 Décembre 1904, à 4h. p.m., sous la présidence de S.E. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky.

M. Escoffier dit que la fusion des services de recettes, décidée par la Délégation, l'amène à Aire part à l'Assemblée d'une proposition faite au Comité des finances tendant à ce que, pour simplifier les opérations de perception, il soit décidé de rendre les taxes portables et non guirables et à réunir sur une même tête les taxes sur la propriété et les loyers afin d'avoir à faire à un nombre moins grand de contri- buables.

M. de Menasce dit que l'adoption de ce sys tème pourrait modifier sensiblement l'organisa tion adoptée par la Délégation pour le service de recettes et qu'il serait done prudent de ne pas ratifier cette organisation avant qu'une dé- cision a'intervienne sur la proposition soumise au Comité des Finances.

M. Chataway dit que l'étude de la proposi tion en question demande un certain temps et qu'en attendant le service doit suivre l'organi- sation nouvelle qui constitue une amélioration à l'état des choses existant.

L'Assemblée renvoie l'étude de la proposi tion de M. Escoffier au Comité du Contentieux. M. Zouro informe qu'il interpellers le Prési- dent à la prochaine séance au sujet d'une ques- tion relative aux poids publics.
M. Suzzarini, en sa qualité de membre du Comité d'hygiène, demande les raisons pour lesquelles ce Comité n'est plus convoqué, chose qui rend son-existence inutile.

M. le Dr.Schiess Bey dit que les réunions du Comité dépendent des questions qui lui sont renvoyées soit par la Commission soit par la Délégation. Or il semble que dans ces derniers temps, il n'y a pas eu de questions importantes nécessitant une étude spéciale de la part du Comité. Padoa bey fait remarquer que les Co- mités ayant un droit de contrôle, il leur est loisible de se saisir de toute question qui les intéresse
A ce sujet, il dépose une proposition tendant à compléter le Comité des travaux publics, le nombre des membres de ce Comité étant dimi- nué par suite de démissions.

Communication est donnée d'une lettre du 6 Décembre de 8. E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur informant que, pour permettre aux administra tions intéressées d'étudier la décision de la Commission relative au Collecteur Eet, il de- mande de tenir en suspens cette délibération. L'Assemblée, sur la proposition de M. Ro- thaker, s'en rapporte à la bienveillance du Gou- vernement pour hiter la solution de cette ques- tion, vu l'urgence qu'elle présente au point de vue du prochain achèvement des filtres, dont ce collecteur gera appelé à drainer les eaux provenant de leur lavage

Lecture est ensuite donnée d'une lettre du Président de la Société archéologique informant que M. Maspero a bien voulu accepter de céder A la ville d'Alexandrie deux obélisques prove- nant des mines de Sax.

La Commission accepte avec remerciements. Communication est donnée d'une lettre de 8.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur informant qu'il estime que l'Administrateur près de la Com- pagnie des Eaux ne peut pas être M. Chataway mais que le choix de la Commission doit s'ar rêter sur une personne qui puisse représenter à la fois les deux intérêts en présence de la Municipalité et du Gouvernement, M. Chata way n'étant que fonctionnaire municipal.

La Commission se référant à une délibéra- tion de la Délégation sur le même objet, ex- prime ses remerciements as Gouvernement pour les sentiments développés dans sa lettre, et d'après lesquels il reconnait l'importance des intérêts de la Municipalité dans la question des rapports de celle-ci avec la Compagnie des Eaux, mais considérant que le choix le plus judicieux à faire serait celui de l'Administra teur de la Municipalité, en raison de la con- naissance plus intime qu'il doit avoir des besoins de la ville, l'Assemblée prie le Gouver nement de revenir sur sa décision, en ap- prouvant la délibération de la Commission du 3 Décembre, étant entendu que l'Assemblée n'a aucune objection à ce que, dans ses rap- ports avec la Compagnie des Eaux, M. Cha taway puisse recevoir directement des instruc- tions du Ministère.
L'ordre du jour appelle la discussion du budget de l'exercice 1905.
Il est donné à ce sujet communication du rapport de M. l'Administrateur et des modifi- cations y apportées par la Délégation ainsi que de la note du Comité financier sur, le dit budget.
Les propositions du Comité quant aux re- cettes sont approuvées et le chiffre en est arrêté à L.E. 188,000.

Au sujet des dépenses, une discussion s'en- gage en ce qui concerne les crédits du person nel, à la suite de laquelle le Comité des finan- ces propose la motion suivante qui est adoptée: "Le Comité des finances propose l'adoption de son rapport, en portant la prévision des dépenses du personnel à LE 46,000, sauf an Comité à étudier le tableau dressé par la Délé- gation indiquant les catégories et le nombre des employés, et après approbation par la Commission du tableau définitif, la Délégation fers les applications individuelles.
"En attendant les appointements resteront tels quels avec les gratifications octroyées
Les propositions de la Délégation et du Comité concernant les allocations sont adoptées Les subventions théâtrales sont ramenées à 900 LE conformément aux propositions du Comité

Il est décidé an sujet des allocations qu'un Comité sers institué au cours de l'exercice prochain pour la revision de toutes les sub- ventions, en vue d'une répartition équitable En conséquence le budget des dépenses est arrêté à LE. 188,000 comprenant une réserve de LE 2090

A l'occasion de la discussion du Budget, M. Rothaker propose de demander au gouverne ment de maintenir pour la ville d'Alexandrie le droit de 500 sur les transferts des proprié tés, en affectant à la Municipalité la réduction de 3 0/0 consentie sur ce droit.

Cette imposition est équitable, car elle ne frapperait que les classes aisées et serait d'une perception facile, indépendamment de ce qu'elle représenterait la rémunération des sacrifices qu'assume la Municipalité, dont les travaux contribuent pour la plus grande part à la plur value des propriétés.
D'un autre côté, cette imposition permettrait de réduire certaines taxes peu sympathiques ou d'une application difficile.
Padoa bey émet un avis contraire à cette proposition et dit qu'il se réserve de la com battre à une prochaine séance.
Le principe établi par le règlement sur la rage proposé par la Délégation et consistant dans le musellement des chiens est adopté, sauf à fixer les termes de l'arrêté y relatif à la prochaine séance.

1° Suppression du texte de l'Art. 30 des

2° Suppression de l'Art. 31 qui sera remplacé comme suit:

"Aucun Administrateur ne sera nommé Administrateur à moins qu'il ne dépos entre les mains de la Société des certificate pour cent actions (et ces certifiests d'ec- tions seront conservés par la Société pen- dont la durée de ses fonctions).

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
div.p: L'Administration des Servies Sanitaires a l'hon near de prier M. les Pharmaciens prop i6- taires de pharmacies, de vouloir bien lui faire connalare avant le 1er janvier 1906, les quartier, rue et numéro où se trouve sitase lear pharmacie, ainsi que la dénomination sous laquelle alle 616 ouverte

Il leur est rappelé que, s'ils sont propriétaires de plasivars pharmacies, ils sont senus d'employer un gérant pour ch seace d'elles, sa dehors de ce le girée par eux personnellement et de se musir d'une autorisation spéciale pour les pharmacies n.n gérées par eux.

La Municipalité d'Alexandrie a déjà en l'honneur d'attirer l'attention du pabiie sur les dangers sérieux saxquels il est exposé à la saise des oss de r-ge qui se sont manifestée plus nomoreax depuis quelque temps. Elle a à ces égard prié M M. les proprié res de chiens, dhate et autres animaux susceptible le rage de pré enir immé tistemeat le sévérinaire municipal (téléphone No. 841) an ose of our ani maux présenteraient des symptome aspecte
A ce sujet la Municipalité erous devoir signaler se css d'une persoane bien connue qui avait éé légère ment mordue par un chien (teau à la saison) ense le 19-24 Octobre dernier.

Il parait que le obien en question ne présentait à ce moment-là anean symptome alarmant pai-que famille a coationé à le garder et en a même fais ondest & toe saire familie près quelques jours. Ce n'est qu'apris une quins ine de jours et après qu'il avait mordu dans ces deux faidos sept per sonnes differentes que cos familles se décidérent à le so metre à un examen vétérinaire qui démontes immédiatement qu'on se trouvais en présence d'an cas de rage fanese
La famille avisée partis immédiatement pour le Caire (yuelques-uns pour Athènes) pour subir le traitemens pasteuries.
Une des personnes mordues retouros du Caire le 24 Novembre 14; le 11 Décembre dernier, les pre miers symptômes de rage se éclarèrent et la m survins 6 jours après

div.head: GUNNY BAG MARKET
div.p: SHRAGER BROS. CALCUTTA MARKET REPORT FOR WEEK ENDING 10th DECEMBER, 1904. We have yet another advance to record prices on the Gunny market, which checks export business, such orders come in for prompt shipment, and very full prices are paid.

Burma and the Far East have been operat ing in both Heavy G and E bags; 8 porter wills are in request for the United Kingdom, while for the Bombay markets and country trade requirements, all parcels of 24lb. This coupled with the upward reaction in the Jute market and the uniform reports that come in from up country in respect to the early closing of the Jute season, are the main factors which have led to the rise;
